subject: Re: [junit] Help: How to derive your own runner from JUnit4ClassRunner

messageBody:
Scott,

I'll first answer your direct question, and then bump the discussion up a level.

To answer your direct question, better support for custom runners that
are really just additions to the JUnit 4 default behavior, like the
one you describe, is still a feature in progress. The class design
simply hasn't calmed down enough to move the classes out of "internal"
and start making iron-clad promises to future extenders.

That said, if you're willing to be flexible, it's not that bad--the
final published interface is likely to be very similar to what's in
JUnit 4.4. You want to extend JUnit4ClassRunner, and probably
override:

- getTestMethods: to pick up @Integration methods as well as @Test methods
- validate: so that a class with only @Integration methods doesn't get
marked as malformed
- wrapMethod: to change method running behavior.

In wrapMethod, you'll want to conditionally return a subclass of
TestMethod, with your behavior inserted. It may be sufficient to
override TestMethod.isIgnored, based on your description.

To bump the discussion up a level, the support for assumptions in
JUnit 4.4 was supposed to handle situations very similar to what
you're describing:

@Test public void integrationWorks() {
assumeTrue(runningIntegrationTests());
// rest of test
}

This test will stop at the first line unless runningIntegrationTests
returns true. If this facility doesn't handle your need, please let
us know, so that we can improve it in future releases. Thanks,

David

On 8/14/07, Scott Zou <zou0s1@...> wrote:
> Hi,
>
> All I want to do is this: I want to mark some of my test methods with my
> own annotation (e.g. @integration) instead of @test. Then when this test
> case runs, these methods will check something like an environment
> variable to determine whether it should run (like @test) or do nothing (like
> @ignore).
>
> I figure I have to derive my own test runners to do this (@runWith
> (myTest.class)). However, since JUnit4ClassRunner is internal and it's
> not documented, where can I find instructions/documents on what and how
> to derive from it? Or is there a better way to achieve what we need here?
>
> Thanks!
